PIONEER EXPERIENCES

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire.

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as all others. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces.

Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

- All questionnaires
- Pioneer diet
- Pioneer schools
- Pioneer churches
- Pioneer recreation and social life
- Pioneer farming experiences
- Folklore in Saskatchewan
- Pioneer health and housing

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

We lived near an Indian Reserve. (Fort Riley Reserve)

We stayed at 20 miles south of Fort Riley.

We later moved to Foster, then in around the year 1933.

Before we came to Canada we farmed after we came here.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

In 1905 a new railway line was built through our district, which brought more landowners and farmers into the area.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

A number returned here in order to work at the mill.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible (such as owning the first automobile, building the first house, etc.).

We bought the first house from Yorkton (approximately) there was a first railroad line around East Kildonan.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, Villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first name was given; (5) reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

The town of Yorkton was called by the railway station's name when it opened in 1905.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons did they have for moving?

In 1905, the Nez Perce District was established.

They bought some land and began growing potatoes and corn.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did any return?

A number returned back to Idaho, but not all.
